name: Coyote
subtitle: The Trickster, Fire-Bringer, Old Man Coyote
description: Coyote is one of the most important and complex figures in Native American mythology, appearing in the traditions of nearly every tribe west of the Mississippi River. He is simultaneously creator and destroyer, wise teacher and utter fool, sacred being and outrageous buffoon. Through his endless scheming, his spectacular failures, and his occasional triumphs, Coyote teaches the deepest truths about human nature, the cosmos, and the delicate balance between chaos and order.
physicalDescription: A shape-shifting figure who typically appears as a coyote but can transform into human or other forms. In human form, often depicted with coyote characteristics such as cunning eyes and tan/yellow coloring.

traditions.name: Ma'ii
traditions.description: A powerful and dangerous figure associated with witchcraft (skinwalkers), but also with the creation of the stars. When the Holy People were carefully placing stars in the sky, impatient Coyote grabbed the blanket and flung the remaining stars across the heavens, creating the Milky Way.

traditions.name: Isaahkawuattee / Old Man Coyote
traditions.description: The primary creator figure who made the earth, animals, and people. He shaped the landscape, taught humans how to live, and established the ceremonies.

traditions.name: Coyote
traditions.description: Central to creation stories and often depicted bringing fire to humanity by stealing it from the Fire Beings, sometimes with the help of other animals in a relay race.

traditions.name: Mica
traditions.description: Appears as a trickster whose stories often serve as cautionary tales about the dangers of greed, lust, and arrogance.

majorStories.title: Coyote Steals Fire
majorStories.narrative: In the time before humans had fire, the Fire Beings jealously guarded it on a distant mountain. Coyote, seeing that the people were cold and suffering, devised a plan. He organized the animals into a relay team stretching from the mountain to the human village. Coyote tricked his way into the Fire Beings' lodge and stole a burning brand, running with it until he was exhausted, then passing it to the next animal - sometimes Squirrel (whose tail was scorched, forever after curled), then Chipmunk (who got his stripes from the Fire Beings' claws), and so on until Frog swallowed the coal and gave it to Wood, where fire lives to this day.
majorStories.teaching: Great gifts often require sacrifice and cooperation. Coyote was burned and nearly killed, but his trickery and determination brought an essential gift to humanity.

majorStories.title: Coyote and the Origin of Death
majorStories.narrative: In many traditions, Coyote is responsible for death entering the world. When the world was new, the beings debated whether death should be permanent. Some argued that the dead should return to life, like the moon waxing after waning. Coyote argued that death should be permanent - 'If the dead came back, there would be no room for the living, no reason to value life.' The others reluctantly agreed. But shortly after, Coyote's own son died. Devastated, Coyote begged to change the rule, but it was too late - his own words had bound the world.
majorStories.teaching: Our actions have consequences we cannot foresee. Even the trickster cannot escape the laws he helps create. Death, though painful, gives meaning to life.

majorStories.title: Coyote and the Monster
majorStories.narrative: In Pacific Northwest and Plateau traditions, Coyote defeats various monsters that threaten the people. Sometimes he allows himself to be swallowed by a great monster, then cuts his way out from within, freeing all the people and animals the monster had eaten. As he cuts up the monster's body and throws the pieces across the land, each piece becomes a different tribe of people, explaining how the various nations came to live where they do.
majorStories.teaching: Sometimes you must enter into danger, even destruction, to bring about liberation. The hero's journey may require being consumed before emerging transformed.

deeperNature: Sacred Chaos: Coyote represents the creative chaos necessary for transformation. Without the trickster's disruption, the world would become rigid and lifeless.
The Shadow: Coyote often acts out the impulses that 'civilized' beings repress. His stories allow communities to acknowledge and laugh at their own shadows.
Boundary Crosser: Coyote moves between worlds - between the sacred and profane, between animal and human, between creation and destruction. He is a mediator.
Teacher Through Failure: Coyote's failures teach more than his successes. We learn from his mistakes without having to make them ourselves.
Eternal Survival: No matter what happens to Coyote - burned, drowned, dismembered - he always returns. He represents the indestructible spirit of life itself.
symbolism: Creator/Destroyer: Coyote makes and unmakes, often in the same story
Sacred/Profane: His stories include both the most holy and the most crude elements - often simultaneously
Wise/Foolish: Coyote's wisdom comes through his foolishness; his foolishness reveals deep wisdom
Survivor: Above all, Coyote survives. The actual coyote animal's adaptability - thriving even as other species disappear - mirrors this spiritual quality
extendedContent.culturalRespect: Coyote stories are living traditions, still told in Native communities today. While some stories are shared publicly, others are restricted to certain seasons or ceremonial contexts. The trickster is not merely entertainment - Coyote is a spiritual teacher whose stories carry power and responsibility.

attributes.namesAcrossTraditions: Ma'ii (Navajo), Isily (Crow), Old Man Coyote, First Angry, Mica (Lakota), Coyote Old Man
attributes.symbols: The coyote animal, fire, the color yellow/tan, footprints, the morning star
attributes.character: Clever yet foolish, creative yet destructive, sacred yet profane, eternal survivor
attributes.primaryRegions: Plains, Southwest, Great Basin, California, Pacific Northwest interior

abilities: Shape-shifting between coyote and human forms
Eternal resurrection - cannot be permanently killed
